introContent.text:
A power (or exponent) shows how many times a number is multiplied by itself.

\(x^n = x \times x \times ... \times x\) (n times)

Understanding powers and exponents is crucial for:

  • Simplifying large calculations
  • Working with scientific notation
  • Solving exponential growth problems

items.title: Product Rule
items.content:
When multiplying powers with the same base, add the exponents:

\(x^m \times x^n = x^{m+n}\)

Example: \(2^3 \times 2^2 = 2^5 = 32\)

items.title: Quotient Rule
items.content:
When dividing powers with the same base, subtract the exponents:

\(\frac{x^m}{x^n} = x^{m-n}\)

Example: \(\frac{2^5}{2^2} = 2^3 = 8\)

items.title: Power Rule
items.content:
When raising a power to another power, multiply the exponents:

\((x^m)^n = x^{m\times n}\)

Example: \((2^3)^2 = 2^6 = 64\)
